additional_lessons.title: Play Action Passing
additional_lessons.description: Learn how play-action fakes manipulate defenses

options_json: QB fakes a handoff then throws
variant.explanation_richtext: Play-action is when the QB fakes a handoff to freeze the defense, then throws a pass. It works best when the run game is effective.

options_json: Defenders bite on the fake and lose coverage
variant.explanation_richtext: When defenders see the run fake, they step forward to stop the run. This creates space behind them for receivers to get open.

options_json: QB fakes handoff then rolls opposite direction
variant.explanation_richtext: A bootleg has the QB fake a handoff one way, then roll out the opposite direction. This often leaves the QB with open field and running options.

options_json: QB has no blockers protecting him
variant.explanation_richtext: A naked bootleg leaves the QB without blocking protection. All linemen block away from the QB's rollout direction, making it risky but effective.

options_json: When the run game is working well
variant.explanation_richtext: Play-action works best when the defense respects your run game. If they're worried about the run, they'll bite harder on the fake.

options_json: Takes longer to develop than quick passes
variant.explanation_richtext: The fake handoff takes extra time, so the QB has their back to the defense longer. This makes play-action vulnerable to blitzes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What formation makes play-action most believable?
variant.explanation_richtext: Play-action looks most like a real run from under center with backs in the backfield. The defense sees a run formation and reacts accordingly.

options_json: Bootleg with a pulling guard for protection
variant.explanation_richtext: A waggle is a bootleg where an offensive lineman (usually a guard) pulls to provide protection for the rolling QB. It's safer than a naked bootleg.

variant.prompt_richtext: On play-action, what does the QB typically look for?
options_json: Receivers running deep behind frozen defenders
variant.explanation_richtext: Play-action is designed to get receivers deep. When linebackers and safeties bite on the fake, receivers get behind them for big plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: Can you run play-action from shotgun?
variant.explanation_richtext: You can fake handoffs from shotgun, but it's less believable since the QB is farther from the RB. Under center fakes look more realistic.

additional_lessons.title: Screen Passes
additional_lessons.description: Learn how screen passes work and when to use them

options_json: Short pass with blockers in front of the receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: A screen pass is a short pass where offensive linemen or other blockers get in front of the receiver to create a 'screen' of blockers.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a running back screen, what do the offensive linemen do?
options_json: Let defenders through, then block downfield
variant.explanation_richtext: On RB screens, linemen intentionally let pass rushers through, then release downfield to block. This tricks the defense into thinking they have a free rush.

variant.prompt_richtext: When is the best time to call a screen pass?
options_json: When the defense is blitzing aggressively
variant.explanation_richtext: Screens work best against blitzes. When defenders rush hard, they run past the screen and can't recover. The blockers have numbers advantage.

options_json: Quick pass to a receiver in the flat with blockers
variant.explanation_richtext: A bubble screen is a quick pass to a receiver in the flat (near the sideline) with other receivers blocking. It's almost like a run play.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does a WR screen differ from a bubble screen?
options_json: WR screens often have linemen pulling to block
variant.explanation_richtext: WR screens often involve offensive linemen releasing downfield to block, while bubble screens use other receivers as blockers. Both are quick passes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'middle screen' or 'jailbreak screen'?
options_json: Screen up the middle with pulling linemen
variant.explanation_richtext: A middle screen goes up the middle of the field with offensive linemen pulling to create a wall of blockers. It's effective when the defense spreads out.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do offensive linemen release downfield on screens?
options_json: To block defenders and create running lanes
variant.explanation_richtext: Linemen release downfield to block linebackers and defensive backs, creating running lanes for the receiver. This turns a pass into a run play.

variant.prompt_richtext: What can defeat a screen pass?
options_json: Disciplined defenders who don't rush hard
variant.explanation_richtext: Screens rely on defenders rushing past the play. If defenders stay disciplined and don't rush hard, they can tackle the receiver before blockers arrive.

options_json: RB pretends to block then slips out for a pass
variant.explanation_richtext: A slip screen has the RB fake blocking a rusher, then 'slip' out to the flat for a quick pass. It's very effective against aggressive pass rushers.

options_json: They punish defenses for being too aggressive
variant.explanation_richtext: Screens 'constrain' or limit defensive aggression. If a defense blitzes too much, screens make them pay. This forces defenses to be more balanced.

additional_lessons.title: Offensive Line Basics
additional_lessons.description: Learn offensive line positions and responsibilities

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the center's primary job?
options_json: Snap the ball to the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: The center snaps (hikes) the ball to the QB to start every play. The center also makes blocking calls and identifies defensive alignments.

variant.prompt_richtext: Where do the guards line up?
options_json: On either side of the center
At the ends of the line
variant.explanation_richtext: The two guards line up on either side of the center. They're typically the most athletic linemen and often 'pull' to lead block on running plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: Where do offensive tackles line up?
options_json: Outside the guards, at the ends of the line
They don't line up on the line
variant.explanation_richtext: Offensive tackles line up outside the guards at the ends of the offensive line. They typically block defensive ends and outside linebackers.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is the left tackle often the highest-paid offensive lineman?
options_json: Protects the QB's blind side (for right-handed QBs)
variant.explanation_richtext: For right-handed QBs, the left tackle protects the 'blind side' - the side the QB can't see while looking downfield. This is the most critical pass protection position.

variant.prompt_richtext: What are 'gaps' in offensive line terminology?
variant.explanation_richtext: Gaps are the spaces between offensive linemen, labeled A (next to center), B (guard-tackle), C (tackle-TE), etc. Running plays target specific gaps.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does it mean when a guard 'pulls'?
options_json: Leaves their position to lead block elsewhere
variant.explanation_richtext: When a guard pulls, they leave their position and run laterally to lead block for a running play. This creates power and numbers advantage at the point of attack.

variant.prompt_richtext: How many offensive linemen are on the field for most plays?
variant.explanation_richtext: There are always 5 offensive linemen: center, 2 guards, and 2 tackles. They're the only players who can't catch forward passes.
A double team has two offensive linemen blocking one defensive player. This is used against strong defenders or to create movement at the point of attack.

options_json: Two linemen double team, then one peels off to block a linebacker
variant.explanation_richtext: A combo block starts as a double team on a defensive lineman, then one blocker 'peels off' to block a linebacker at the second level. It's fundamental to zone blocking.
Line splits are the spacing between offensive linemen. Wider splits create bigger running lanes but make pass protection harder. Splits vary by play type.

additional_lessons.title: Run Blocking Schemes
additional_lessons.description: Learn the two main run blocking philosophies

variant.prompt_richtext: In zone blocking, what do offensive linemen block?
variant.explanation_richtext: Zone blocking has linemen block areas (zones) rather than specific defenders. They work together to create running lanes wherever the defense is weakest.

variant.prompt_richtext: In gap (or man) blocking, what do offensive linemen do?
variant.explanation_richtext: Gap or man blocking assigns each lineman a specific defender to block. The play is designed to go to a specific gap regardless of defensive alignment.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main advantage of zone blocking?
options_json: Adapts to defensive movement, RB finds the best hole
variant.explanation_richtext: Zone blocking is flexible - linemen work together to block areas, and the RB reads the defense to find the best hole. It adapts to what the defense does.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the main advantage of gap blocking?
options_json: More physical and powerful at the point of attack
variant.explanation_richtext: Gap blocking is more physical - linemen drive specific defenders backward. It's less flexible but more powerful when you want to impose your will.

options_json: Linemen block laterally, RB runs to the edge
variant.explanation_richtext: Outside zone has linemen block laterally toward the sideline, creating running lanes on the edge. The RB reads blocks and can cut inside or bounce outside.

options_json: Zone blocking up the middle between the tackles
variant.explanation_richtext: Inside zone is zone blocking aimed at the interior gaps (A, B gaps). Linemen work laterally but the play targets inside running lanes.

options_json: Gap blocking with a pulling guard leading
variant.explanation_richtext: Power is a gap blocking scheme where a guard pulls to lead block through a specific gap. It's a physical, downhill running play.

options_json: RB fakes one direction, then runs the opposite way
variant.explanation_richtext: A counter has the RB take a step one direction (to freeze the defense), then run the opposite way with pulling blockers. It's effective against aggressive defenses.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'reach block' in zone blocking?
options_json: Blocker tries to get outside shoulder of defender
variant.explanation_richtext: A reach block has the blocker try to get to the outside shoulder of the defender, sealing them inside. This creates running lanes on the edge.

options_json: Let a defender through, then block them from the side
variant.explanation_richtext: A trap intentionally lets a defensive lineman through unblocked, then a pulling guard 'traps' them from the side. The RB runs through the created gap.

additional_lessons.title: Pass Protection
additional_lessons.description: Learn how offensive lines protect the quarterback

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the offensive line's job on passing plays?
options_json: Protect the QB from pass rushers
variant.explanation_richtext: On passing plays, the offensive line must protect the QB from defensive pass rushers, giving the QB time to find open receivers and throw.

options_json: Each blocker is assigned a specific rusher
Only one blocker protects the QB
variant.explanation_richtext: Man protection assigns each blocker a specific pass rusher to block. If the defense brings more rushers than blockers, someone comes free.

options_json: Blockers protect areas and pass off rushers
Each blocker has a specific assignment
variant.explanation_richtext: Zone protection has blockers protect areas and pass off rushers to each other. It's more flexible against stunts and twists but requires communication.

options_json: Line slides together in one direction to pick up rushers
variant.explanation_richtext: Slide protection has the entire line slide together (usually toward the RB) to pick up rushers. The RB protects the opposite side. It's a zone protection concept.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the 'pocket' in pass protection?
options_json: Protected area around the QB created by blockers
variant.explanation_richtext: The pocket is the protected area around the QB formed by offensive linemen. A good pocket gives the QB space to step up and throw.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a 'hot route' in pass protection?
options_json: Quick route when the defense blitzes
variant.explanation_richtext: When the defense brings more rushers than blockers, the QB throws a 'hot route' - a quick pass to where the blitzer came from. It neutralizes the blitz.

options_json: RB or TE briefly blocks then releases into route
variant.explanation_richtext: A chip block has a RB or TE give a quick block to slow down a rusher, then release into their pass route. It helps the tackle and gets the player into the pattern.

options_json: Using RBs and TEs to help block, fewer receivers
variant.explanation_richtext: Max protection keeps RBs and TEs in to block, giving maximum protection (7-8 blockers) but fewer receivers. It's used for deep passes or against heavy blitzes.

options_json: Paths rushers take to get to the QB
Lanes for the QB to run
variant.explanation_richtext: Pass rush lanes are the paths defenders take to rush the QB - typically inside, outside, or up the middle. Blockers must control these lanes.

options_json: Protection breakdowns or QB holding ball too long
variant.explanation_richtext: Sacks usually result from protection breakdowns (missed blocks, wrong assignments) or the QB holding the ball too long. Good protection requires all 11 players executing.

additional_lessons.title: Pre-Snap Reads
additional_lessons.description: Learn how offenses adjust before the snap

options_json: QB analyzes the defense before the snap
variant.explanation_richtext: Pre-snap reads are when the QB analyzes the defensive alignment before the snap to identify coverage, potential blitzes, and favorable matchups.

options_json: QB changes the play at the line of scrimmage
variant.explanation_richtext: An audible is when the QB changes the play call at the line of scrimmage based on what they see in the defense. It's also called 'checking out' of a play.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do offenses use pre-snap motion?
options_json: To identify man vs zone coverage
variant.explanation_richtext: Pre-snap motion helps identify coverage. If a defender follows the motion, it's likely man coverage. If defenders pass off, it's zone coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why does the QB identify the 'Mike' linebacker?
options_json: Sets the protection scheme for the offensive line
variant.explanation_richtext: Identifying the 'Mike' (middle linebacker) sets the protection scheme. Blockers count from the Mike to know their assignments. The Mike isn't always the actual MLB.

options_json: Multiple players change positions before the snap
variant.explanation_richtext: A shift has multiple offensive players change positions before the snap. They must set for one second before the snap. Shifts can confuse defensive alignments.

options_json: QB uses voice inflection to draw defense offsides
variant.explanation_richtext: A hard count uses voice inflection and cadence changes to try to make the defense jump offsides. The QB makes it sound like the snap is coming.

options_json: QB cancels the play, goes to backup play
variant.explanation_richtext: A kill call cancels the original play and activates a pre-determined backup play. It's used when the original play won't work against the defensive look.

options_json: Counting defenders near the line of scrimmage
variant.explanation_richtext: Counting the box means counting how many defenders are near the line (in the 'box'). If there are more defenders than blockers, the QB might audible to a pass.

options_json: Fake audible to confuse the defense
variant.explanation_richtext: A dummy call is a fake audible - the QB yells signals but doesn't actually change the play. It's used to keep the defense guessing about real audibles.

options_json: The signal that tells the center when to snap the ball
Number of snaps in the game
variant.explanation_richtext: The snap count is the predetermined signal (like 'hut' or a number) that tells the center when to snap the ball. Varying the count can draw the defense offsides.
